docs.lead_paragraph: The day of reckoning for Dr. Diane E. Meier, a geriatrician at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, came a decade ago when she encountered a 73-year-old man with terminal lung cancer. His hands and feet were tied to the bed because he repeatedly pulled out the feeding tube inserted through his nose, despite his explicit wish that he receive no treatment. ''What's going on here?'' Dr. Meier asked the resident on duty. ''This man is dying. Why is he tied to the bed?''

headline.main: SCIENTIST AT WORK/Diane Meier; Providing Care, When the Cure Is Out of Reach

docs.abstract: Lilian and Benjamin Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute at Mount Sinai Medical Center, directed by geriatrician Dr Diane E Meier, strives to take care of those patients dealing with physical and emotional suffering by offering solutions to improve quality of life and not necessarily to provide treatment to cure patients; estimated 1,500 hospitals have palliative care department compared with just 100 five years ago; financial constraints are shown to be primary stumbling block to continued growth; article calls for change in medical philosophy that would uncouple palliative care from terminal illness and provide for patients of all ages with all types of medical concerns; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, before entering the hospital for elective surgery, I appointed my husband as my health care proxy in case something happened to impair my ability to make decisions about further treatment. We had often discussed our unwillingness to be kept alive by machines if meaningful recovery was not possible, but I put it in writing on New York State's health care proxy form, with my signature witnessed by two friends. So did my husband.

headline.main: Name a Proxy Early to Prepare for the Unexpected

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten years ago I was on vacation, sitting at a harborside restaurant in Baltimore sipping a daiquiri. We had planned to leave the next morning on a daylong Chesapeake Bay cruise. With that drink my whole world, and my perception of myself in it, changed. As I watched my husband point to a boat bobbing in the sunset, I realized that something felt wrong. I'd had this feeling before. I was lightheaded, but somehow that wasn't all. The lights were too bright, the colors too vibrant, the sounds too loud, and it seemed as if time was moving too slow. I could follow the conversation but couldn't join in. That's what I remember before my head hit the table.

docs.lead_paragraph: When a new therapy performs extraordinarily well in clinical tests and is widely publicized and licensed, excitement mounts. But after hundreds of thousands of patients receive the new treatment, unexpected problems can turn up to temper the enthusiasm. Sometimes the problems occur along a learning curve as doctors master a new technique, like implanting drug-coated stents in coronary arteries. Other times, when a particular size of new device is in short supply immediately after it is marketed, patient demand may pressure doctors to improvise and stretch the rules set by the Food and Drug Administration.

headline.main: Doctors Look for Source of Stent Complications

docs.lead_paragraph: Women whose second child had a father different from the first child's were at higher risk for birth complications, a new study has found. Researchers in Norway based the conclusion on a study of births by almost 500,000 women over a 20-year period. Their report appears in BMJ, a British medical journal.

docs.lead_paragraph: People who buy dietary supplements to ease the pain and stiffness of arthritis are generally getting what they pay for, an independent testing company has found. But some people -- especially those who buy the supplements for their pets -- may not be getting what they think they are, the company says. The company, ConsumerLab.com, tested 49 products that contain glucosamine, chondroitin and MSM, ingredients that some have found useful in keeping joints mobile and reducing arthritis pain.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite clear evidence that newborns feel pain, most premature infants are given no analgesics in hospitals, even though they are regularly subjected to painful procedures, a new study reports. Writing in the current Archives of Pediatrics & Adolescent Medicine, researchers said that only about a third of infants studied had received appropriate pain control while they were in a neonatal intensive care unit.

headline.main: Easing the Pain of Tiniest Babies

docs.lead_paragraph: For the 2-year-old twins Ahmed and Mohamed Ibrahim, it has been a month of firsts: the first time they have ever slept in separate beds, sat upright or seen each other face to face. The brothers, born joined at the tops of their heads in Egypt, were separated in a 33-hour operation that concluded on Oct. 12 at Children's Hospital of Dallas. Today, they blow kisses and throw toys at visitors, hold each other's hands and appear to understand both English and Arabic, their mother, Sabah Abou Al Wafa, said in a recent interview at the hospital, speaking in Arabic through a translator.

headline.main: No Longer Joined, Boys Face Tough Journey

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who smoke are at much higher risk for bleeding strokes, but those who have quit can bring their risk back to normal, researchers have found. The study found that women who smoked 15 or more cigarettes a day were more than twice as likely to suffer this kind of stroke, described as hemorrhagic, which causes severe injury and often death. And the more they smoke, the higher the risk, according to a report in the current online issue of the journal Stroke.

headline.main: Stroke Risk: The Rise and Fall
